candidates.title: Are These Towering Snow Walls in Massachusetts?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows snow walls lining a highway in Massachusetts.
Rating:
Miscaptioned
About this rating
A photograph showing high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway has been circulating on the Internet since at least 2007. Popular memes have claimed (for humorous effect) that the picture was taken in Massachusetts, or (less homorously) in Canada:
The image actually captures a stretch of road near the Japanese city of Towada in Aomori prefecture.
The photograph was taken by Mihai Apostu and posted to his blog, "A Romanian in Japan," in April 2007:
Before heading down town we decided to take a walk up to Towada. On the way to Towada starting from April thh Gold Line Route is opened. This year's amount of snow was smaller than last year but the Hakkoda Walls are still big. Last year the walls of snow on both sides of the road were 9( nine) metres tall. This year there were only 6 metres of snow that guided us to Tsuta Onsen.
According to a sightseeing guide for the Aomori region of Japan, the Hakkoda Walls are quite a tourist attraction. Heavy snowfalls frequently close the corridor during the winter, but when the spring season approaches the Hakkoda Snowplow Squad gets to work and clears the road:
National Highway 103, commonly known as the Hakkoda-Towada Gold Line, is a popular sightseeing route in Aomori.8 km of this Hakkoda-Towada Gold Line stretching from Sukayu to Yachi Hot Springs is closed off in winter, but thanks to the efforts of the Hakkoda Snowplow Squad, they plow through the snow from both ends to meet at Kasamatsu Pass in late March, creating a stunning snow corridor.
In some places the walls of snow reach a height of 9 m, allowing visitors to enjoy magnificent views of the vivid blue of the sky contrasted against the white of the snow in perfect harmony.
The road opens to general traffic on April 1, but before this, a Hakkoda walk is held every year to walk through this snow corridor, and many people take part in the event.
candidates.description: The walls are formed with specially-designed snow plows.

result.explanation: Source 1 explicitly states that a photograph showing high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway has been circulating online. While the location is clarified to be Japan, not Massachusetts, the core description of the image aligns with the caption.
result.supporting_points: A photograph showing high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway has been circulating on the Internet since at least 2007.

final_result.explanation: The internal validation correctly identifies that the image depicts high snow walls along a highway, but it incorrectly states the location as Massachusetts. The external validation provides strong evidence supporting the core description of the image—high snow walls along a highway—but corrects the location to Japan.  The discrepancy lies solely in the location. The image itself clearly shows a highway with significant snow accumulation forming high walls on either side. This visual evidence aligns with both the internal and external checks' core description.  The internal check's low confidence reflects the location error, while the external check's higher confidence stems from corroborating information and the widespread circulation of the image, thus suggesting that the location information is an error. Given that the core description of the image ('high walls of snow lining the edges of a highway') is accurate, and the location is a supplementary detail, the primary focus should be on the correct visual representation. The internal check’s 100% confidence in a false location negates its value for assessing the accuracy of the caption's core description. The external check's 80% confidence stems from multiple sources corroborating the image's widespread circulation, thus indicating that the image's description is widely confirmed even with location discrepancy. Therefore, the final assessment concludes the caption is out-of-context primarily because of the incorrect location. The confidence score reflects the external validation’s high confidence in the core image description, despite the location error. There is no evidence of visual tampering or miscontextualization.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal validation correctly identifies the image's core elements but incorrectly identifies the location. External validation confirms the image's description but corrects the location. The discrepancy is confined to the location detail; the core description remains consistent across all assessments.  The final judgment is that the caption is out-of-context due to the incorrect location.
